Input.threadtitle: L15S3 Multithreading in GPU
Input.posts:
It was said that modern GPUs use multithreading inside a multiprocessor to hide latency when a certain SIMD lane needs to read from VRAM. What happens, if latencies are different for different lanes inside one multiprocessor (e. g., one lane hit L2$ and another missed)? Will all lanes be switched to other threads or only those stucked? If the latter, what the program counter (which is single for all the SIMD lanes) be like?
Upvotes:
0
Essentially thread scheduler in GPU is free to schedule different lanes in every clock cycle, so it doesn't really matter which lane gets selected next. GPU will be utilized as long as you've some work for it.
Upvotes:
0
That doesn't really answer the question. What is the program counter value then? Inside one thread multiprocessor you need to have the same PC for all SIMD lanes. If you schedule different lanes, essentially, you might need to execute different commands.
Upvotes:
0
>> Inside one thread multiprocessor you need to have the same PC for all SIMD lanes. If i'm not mistake, the SIMD lane is the same as warp - group of 32 threads or some other number of threads. So, you don't have to 'have the same PC for all SIMD lanes', just same PC for all threads in warp or lane. So, perhaps each SIMD lane should have it's own instruction pointer. At least this should solve problem and it is easy to implement. PS: Hello from MSU, Peter! :)
Upvotes:
0
Nope, you get it wrong. SIMD lane is, effectively, a single thread inside a thread group. So the question, in CUDA terms, is: if ONE thread inside the thread group is stalled by a memory fetch, do ALL the threads switch to other threads with the same PC to hide this latency? If not, switching just some of the threads would result in threads having different PCs inside the same thread block.
Upvotes:
0
These 'lanes' are 'threads' in CUDA and C++ AMP terminology, and 'work items' in OpenCL terminology. You only need the same PC across these lanes/threads/items within the same 'wrap' (CUDA) / 'work group' (OpenCL) / 'tile' (C++ AMP), but you don't need to have the same PC between wraps/groups/tiles. This makes sense - you can have a program that has a thread count higher than the GPU threads, when different wraps/groups/tiles will be scheduled sequentially (for instance, when there are enough resource for only 4 wraps, a program of 8 wraps will be executed in two parts, first the first 4 wraps, and when they finished, the last 4). A wrap/group/tile only gets scheduled by the GPU when all data for all lanes/threads/items is available, simple as that. A load instruction is only finished (commits to PRF) when all threads in the wrap are completed.

0
Yes. If half the group continues, other half is stalled, then by definition you have different PCs within the group, and that cannot happen...

Input.threadtitle: Victim Cache and Write Buffer
Input.posts:
What is the difference between a Victim Cache and a Write Buffer?I have gone through some of the contents in the internet which say sometimes write buffers are called Victim cache. I am confused with this.
Upvotes:
0
Victim cache contains the dirty line that needs to be written back to the next level (e.g. L2/3 or main memory). It is the result of a load or store miss (if write allocate) that matches the address of the existing line, if multi set way associative, the line contains a LRU status bit that selects it as a 'victim'. In this context, one bit mentions that the line is not up to date w/ its next level memory, hence it has been modified during code execution. Write buffer contains the consecutive store data instructions. I guess it is used for all store access types, write through-write back and no write allocate, write allocate. It is sort of temp buffer that one can use for OOO memory instructions.
Upvotes:
1
Both the write buffer (in the case of write-back cache) and the victim cache hold recently evicted cache lines (In the case of the write-through cache, the buffer holds all writes to the cache). The difference is in the purpose of these structures: - the write buffer holds the evicted cache line in order not to block the memory system until the data is written to a slower memory level - the victim cache holds the recently evicted cache lines, which were evicted because of the low associativity of the cache. The victim cache is fully associative, therefore increases associativity for conflicting (aliasing) cache lines. These evicted lines are therefore available immediately, without the need to reload these from a slower memory level.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Josph Cesana is correct. \xA0The victim cache is used to hold evicted lines on their way out to the next level in the memory hierarchy. \xA0This is beneficial since, if your working set has a set of memory locations that all alias to the same set in your cache, but there are more memory locations than ways in your cache, the victim cache can help to prevent these lines from thrashing. \xA0It essentially can extend the associativity of any set in your cache if it is needed. \xA0The victim cache must be checked in addition to the cache to determine a hit or miss. \xA0Lines in a victim cache may not try to write back to the next level memory immediately or it may just do write through so the victim cache is always up to date with the next level memory. The write buffer also holds evicted lines on their way out to the next level in the memory hierarchy, however has a slightly different purpose. \xA0As is mentioned in the lecture on write buffers, the write buffer handles the case where a miss occurs and must bring in a new cache line that aliases to a line in your cache that is dirty. \xA0Thus, you must write back the dirty line. \xA0Instead of writing back the dirty line, waiting for that to occur, and then loading the data into the now free entry in your cache, you can instead write the evicted line to the write buffer and do the read to the next level memory. \xA0This problem is mainly due to the fact that you generally only have one port to the next level in the memory hierarchy, thus you cannot write back the dirty line and load the new data at the same time. \xA0In addition, if you have a writethrough cache, all your stores will go into the write buffer to reduce the bandwidth demand on your next level memory. \xA0Write buffers also can do write coalescing, to reduce the bandwidth demand on your next level memory. \xA0This does not necessarily have to be checked when accessing your cache, but may be checked when accessing the next level memory. \xA0Write buffers are not meant to be able to extend the associativity of a set in your cache, but is meant to solve the problem of having only one port and too little bandwidth to your next level memory. These structures are similar as you mentioned, however the concepts are different. \xA0You could probably build a single structure that is both a victim cache and a write buffer. \xA0However, there are slight differences between the structures if you listen to the lectures carefully and think about how you would implement them.

What is the difference between a Victim Cache and a Write Buffer?I have gone through some of the contents in the internet which say sometimes write buffers are called Victim cache. I am confused with this.
Upvotes:
0
Victim cache contains the dirty line that needs to be written back to the next level (e.g. L2/3 or main memory). It is the result of a load or store miss (if write allocate) that matches the address of the existing line, if multi set way associative, the line contains a LRU status bit that selects it as a 'victim'. In this context, one bit mentions that the line is not up to date w/ its next level memory, hence it has been modified during code execution. Write buffer contains the consecutive store data instructions. I guess it is used for all store access types, write through-write back and no write allocate, write allocate. It is sort of temp buffer that one can use for OOO memory instructions.
Upvotes:
1
Both the write buffer (in the case of write-back cache) and the victim cache hold recently evicted cache lines (In the case of the write-through cache, the buffer holds all writes to the cache). The difference is in the purpose of these structures: - the write buffer holds the evicted cache line in order not to block the memory system until the data is written to a slower memory level - the victim cache holds the recently evicted cache lines, which were evicted because of the low associativity of the cache. The victim cache is fully associative, therefore increases associativity for conflicting (aliasing) cache lines. These evicted lines are therefore available immediately, without the need to reload these from a slower memory level.

Instructor's Post
Josph Cesana is correct. \xA0The victim cache is used to hold evicted lines on their way out to the next level in the memory hierarchy. \xA0This is beneficial since, if your working set has a set of memory locations that all alias to the same set in your cache, but there are more memory locations than ways in your cache, the victim cache can help to prevent these lines from thrashing. \xA0It essentially can extend the associativity of any set in your cache if it is needed. \xA0The victim cache must be checked in addition to the cache to determine a hit or miss. \xA0Lines in a victim cache may not try to write back to the next level memory immediately or it may just do write through so the victim cache is always up to date with the next level memory. The write buffer also holds evicted lines on their way out to the next level in the memory hierarchy, however has a slightly different purpose. \xA0As is mentioned in the lecture on write buffers, the write buffer handles the case where a miss occurs and must bring in a new cache line that aliases to a line in your cache that is dirty. \xA0Thus, you must write back the dirty line. \xA0Instead of writing back the dirty line, waiting for that to occur, and then loading the data into the now free entry in your cache, you can instead write the evicted line to the write buffer and do the read to the next level memory. \xA0This problem is mainly due to the fact that you generally only have one port to the next level in the memory hierarchy, thus you cannot write back the dirty line and load the new data at the same time. \xA0In addition, if you have a writethrough cache, all your stores will go into the write buffer to reduce the bandwidth demand on your next level memory. \xA0Write buffers also can do write coalescing, to reduce the bandwidth demand on your next level memory. \xA0This does not necessarily have to be checked when accessing your cache, but may be checked when accessing the next level memory. \xA0Write buffers are not meant to be able to extend the associativity of a set in your cache, but is meant to solve the problem of having only one port and too little bandwidth to your next level memory. These structures are similar as you mentioned, however the concepts are different. \xA0You could probably build a single structure that is both a victim cache and a write buffer. \xA0However, there are slight differences between the structures if you listen to the lectures carefully and think about how you would implement them.

Input.threadtitle: MIPS? Why?
Input.posts:
As was stated in the lecture this course will focus on MIPS. Wondering - why? x86 and ARM have most of the CPU market share and therefore of interest to most of the course takers - why not concentrate on them? My personal interest would be 90% for x86 and 10% for others - will x86 be covered in detail here? Thanks
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
MIPS is a relatively simple, RISC (reduced instruction set computing) ISA that many people who have taken introductory computer architecture are familiar with. \xA0Thus, it is a good common point to start from. \xA0 That being said, the main focus of this course is on advanced techniques used in processor design that are mainly independent of the ISA. \xA0It is not a survey of different ISAs and their features. \xA0You can get that from reading ISA manuals. \xA0However, this course does touch on concepts that are exposed to the ISA, such as very long instruction word (VLIW) processors. \xA0 MIPS is simply used as a reference ISA for conveying ideas through code examples and for problem sets and exams. \xA0The course could be taught with any ISA. \xA0However, again, the core material is not to learn new ISAs. \xA0MIPS is simple and familiar, that is the main reason.

Input.threadtitle: L6S4 : Why keep the Instruction in the Issue Queue till the End of the pipe?
Input.posts:
SD5 Slides 36 & 37. For the IO3 processor, why not remove the instructions from the Issue queue as soon as the Instructions are actually Issued. \xA0 Though the instructor mentions though the Instruction could be removed as soon as an Instruction is Issued, the entries in the Issue queue are Valid till end of the pipe. This makes it convenient\xA0to mark the other other pending bits as being Valid ( once a Register is written in the Writeback stage). \xA0I did not quite understand that. The problem that I see is\xA0 \xA0 - The Issue queue \xA0has no structures for pipeline timing ( as shown on Slide 37 ) - instead the pipeline timing is derived from the scoreboard. \xA0- The Scoreboard can by itself be used to determine what \xA0Register is in the Writeback stage, and this information could be used to update the Pending bits in the Issue queue.\xA0 \xA0 So why maintain an Instruction in the Issue queue till end of the pipe i.e the Write-back stage?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I do not see anything fundamental that requires the instruction to stay in the issue queue. \xA0This is mainly an implementation dependent detail. \xA0It could probably be implemented either way. \xA0The instructor may be pointing out that it may make an implementation simpler to keep them in the issue queue. \xA0It may be more convenient to have details about which register is committing on this cycle in the issue queue, as you wouldn't have to cross check the issue queue with the scoreboard. \xA0I think as long as you understand the concept of the issue queue you are fine, as these details only matter when it comes down to actually implementing it. \xA0Questions on problem sets and exams in this course generally do not focus on implementation dependent details like this, so don't worry too much about that. \xA0If you are just curious, then try implementing it and seeing if you can make it work by removing instructions from the issue queue.
